h:head.h:title: OSCE GNM_2nd Year _Administering a blood transfusion

select1.label: Goal: The patient receives the blood transfusion without any evidence of a transfusion reaction or complication. Identify the patient. Ask the patient if he/she is allergic to any medication, iodine, tape or if he/she has had a transfusion or transfusion reaction in the past.

Determine whether the patient knows the reason for the blood transfusion. Explain to the patient what will happen. Check for signed consent for the transfusion if required by agency. Advise the patient to report any chills, itching, rash, or unusual symptoms. If the physician has ordered any premedication, administer it now.
Perform hand hygiene and put on clean gloves.
Hang container of 0.9% normal saline with blood administration set to initiate IV infusion and follow administration of blood.
Start the IV with 18 or 19 gauge catheter if not already present (see Skill 46-1). Keep the IV open by starting the flow of normal saline.
Obtain blood product from the blood bank according to agency policy. Scan for bar codes on blood products if required.
Complete identification and checks as required by agency: identification number; blood group and type; expiration date; patient's name; inspect blood for clots.
Take a baseline set of vital signs before beginning the transfusion.
Start infusion of the blood product:
Start the administration slowly (no more than 25 to 50 mL for the first 15 minutes). Stay with the patient for the first 5 to 15 minutes of transfusion.
Check vital signs at least every 15 minutes for the first half hour. Follow the institution's recommendations for taking vital signs during the remainder of the transfusion.
Observe patient for flushing, dyspnea, itching, hives, or rash or any unusual comments.
Never warm blood in a microwave. Use a blood warming device, if indicated or ordered, especially with rapid transfusions through a CVP catheter.

Maintain the prescribed flow rate as ordered or as deemed appropriate based on the patient's overall condition, keeping in mind the outer limits for safe administration. Ongoing monitoring is crucial throughout the entire duration of the blood transfusion for early identification of any adverse reactions. Assess frequently for transfusion reaction. Stop the blood transfusion if you suspect a reaction. Quickly replace the blood tubing with new tubing and 0.9% sodium chloride. Notify the physician and blood bank.
When the transfusion is complete, clamp off blood and begin to infuse 0.9% normal saline.
Record the administration of blood and the patient's reaction as ordered by agency. Return the blood transfusion bag to the blood bank according to agency policy.
